Midjourney has just released a new feature â€” a highly anticipated new capability called â€œCharacter Referencesâ€. It allows you to specify a reference images that define the character you want to maintain across images.

â€œCharacter Referenceâ€ works well with replicating one single character, what about Multiple Characters? ğŸ

In this guide, I will share my 3 Advanced Skills to Master Character Consistency including generating multiple consistent characters like this image below.

Todayâ€™s content will be broken down into three sections starting with a brief description of the new feature

Part One: What is â€œCharacter Referenceâ€

Part Two: How to use â€œCharacter Referenceâ€

Part Three: 3 Advanced Tips to Use â€œCharacter Referenceâ€

Part One: What is â€œCharacter Referenceâ€ ğŸ¨

â€œCharacter Referenceâ€ allows us to create a character based on the image(s) of an existing character provided via URLs.

It aims to make the character match a reference image, allowing us to create a consistent character across images and in different styles.

Highlight Features

âš’ï¸ Functionality: This feature is similar to regular image prompts except it â€˜focusesâ€™ on the character traits

ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Use: Type --cref URL after your prompt with a URL to an image of a character

ğŸ“ Format: /imagine text prompt --cref URL

ğŸ–¼ï¸ Compatibility: Works for both Midjournvey V6 and Niji 6

Modify with --cw

You can use --cw to modify reference 'strength' from 0â€“100

--cw 100 (default) uses the face, hair, and clothes

--cw 0 focus on face

ğŸ“š Quick Guide with 3 Tips

Learn more about the basics including working on Midjourney website and using multiple references:

Midjourney V6 NEW â€œCharacter Referenceâ€ is Here ğŸ”¥ Maintain Consistent Character

A Quide to Maintain a Consistent Character for Storytelling, Styling and More!

bootcamp.uxdesign.cc

Part Two: How to use â€œCharacter Referenceâ€

Step 1: Choose Your Reference Image

Use an image you generated with Midjourney or pick one online.

Step 2: Upload an Image or Copy a URL

Upload the images with the â€œ+â€ side. Copy the image URL.

Step 3: Type Your Prompt

Type/imagineas you usually do. Then, input your prompt to describe the image you want to generate and add--cref URL

ğŸ”¥Part Three: 3 Advanced Tips to Master Character Consistency

You can make more customization with parameters and prompt weight. In this section, I will go over a few tricks that you can use to adjust the style of your resulting image:

Tip 1: Transform Style with --cw

Tip 2: Create Multiple Consistent Characters with â€œPanâ€

Tip 3: Create Multiple Consistent Characters in A Different Style

â­ï¸ Advanced Tip One: Transform Style with --cw

With --cw, you can transform fictional characters into photographs, and vice-versa. You can use --cw to modify reference 'strength' from 100 to 0.

First, letâ€™s see how the weights affect the outcome.

ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Hereâ€™s what --cw does:

--cw 100 is default and uses the face, hair, and clothes

--cw 99 to --cw 1 will begin to pick up less of the whole character

At Strength 0 --cw 0 will pick up ONLY the face

ğŸ‘¯â€â™€ï¸ Transform Style with --cw 0

With --cw 0, the system will focus on the face which is good for changing outfits/hair etc.

This works roughly like a â€œFace-Swapâ€. It is good for transforming a complete art style

Just add the style to the prompt

1. Cyberpunk style--cref URL --cw 0

2. Digital patining of the girl drinking coffee--cref URL --cw 0

3. A girl reading in the library --cref URL --cw 0

4. A girl standing beside the neon light --cref URL --cw 0

ğŸ“Œ With --cw 0, the system will prioritize the face, making it easier for you to adjust the hair, outfit, and overall art style.

â­ï¸ Advanced Tip Two: Create Multiple Consistent Characters with â€œPanâ€

The best way to put multiple â€œcref-basedâ€ characters in an image is to use â€œPANâ€ â€” a feature that expands the image canvas in a chosen direction

Letâ€™s start

Step 1: Turn on High Variation Mode

First, use /settings to turn â€œRemix modeâ€ on, and select â€œHigh Variation Modeâ€.

ğŸ“Œ This allows you to change your prompt when panning.

Step 2: Select the image that will have a second character with it.

Find the image and upscale the selected image with the â€œUâ€ buttons

Step 3: Use â€œPanâ€

Use â€œPanâ€ and select the direction â¡ï¸â¬…ï¸â¬†ï¸â¬‡ï¸ where the new character should go.

Step 4: Add the second character by changing the prompt

Describe the scene and details of how you want the second character to appear in the image with a prompt and its --cref URL

The Result

This will stitch a new strip of canvas with the new character.

Repeat the same steps with the same --cref URL

You can keep creating different scenes and add a second character with the same --cref URL of the guy

ğŸ“Œ Tip:

Sometimes the image can look a bit awkward, try:

- Add more details if you are looking for more precise generation.

- Make adjustment with Varyâ€Regionâ€

Henrique Centieiro & Bee Lee has also published an article sharing another technique using â€œVary Regionâ€. Bee is an amazing writer for Midjourney. Feel free to check it out:

ğŸ‘±ğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸ğŸ‘©ğŸ» Create Consistent *Multiple* Characters on MidJourney â€” Use This Simple Hack! âœ¨

Unveiling the Powerful Hack I Discovered While Experimenting with MidJourneyâ€™s New â€œCharacter Referenceâ€ Feature

henriquecentieiro.medium.com

â­ï¸ Advanced Tip Three: Create Multiple Consistent Characters in A Different Style

Here is an even more advanced step to bring your creation to the next level!

We can change the overall styles of both characters while maintaining consistency like the image below.

Letâ€™s create a new style for each of the characters

Step 1: Change the Style with --cw 0 ( refer back to Tip 1)

Remember what we did with --cw 0. We can change the style for each of the characters and keep the face using --cw 0

Prompt: In cyberpunk style --cref URL --cw 0

Step 2: Save the New URL

Save the URL for the male character which will be used with --cref

Step 3: Pan the image of the lady

Upscale the image of one of the characters. Repeat the steps of panning the image and enter a prompt with the new --cref URL.

This will stitch a new strip of canvas with the new character on it in a completely different style!

Add in more setting and dynamics with â€œZoomâ€ and â€œVary Regionâ€

More to Note for â€œCharacter Referenceâ€

âœ… This feature works best when using characters made from Midjourney images. Itâ€™s not designed for real people/photos (and will likely distort them as regular image prompts do)

âœ… Cref works similarly to regular image prompts except it â€˜focusesâ€™ on the visual traits of the character

âœ… Character attributes work well with BIG attributes like curly hair, pink sunglasses

âŒ It wonâ€™t copy tiny details like exact dimples, freckles / or t-shirt logos.
